message.content:
We start by extracting the key figures (all values are taken as the End_amount from the balance sheet):

1. Current Assets = 22,474,420.77  
   Current Liabilities = 3,143,833.89  

• Current Ratio = Current Assets / Current Liabilities  
  = 22,474,420.77 / 3,143,833.89  
  ≈ 7.15

2. Inventory = 6,600,000.00  
 For the Quick Ratio, we subtract Inventory from Current Assets:  
  Quick Assets = Current Assets – Inventory  
    = 22,474,420.77 – 6,600,000.00  
    = 15,874,420.77  
• Quick Ratio = Quick Assets / Current Liabilities  
  = 15,874,420.77 / 3,143,833.89  
  ≈ 5.05

3. Total Assets = 33,082,821.36  
   Note: In this case, the only liabilities provided are the current liabilities.
• Debt to Asset Ratio = Total Liabilities / Total Assets  
  = 3,143,833.89 / 33,082,821.36  
  ≈ 0.095 (which we round to 0.10)

4. Total Owner's Equity = 29,938,987.47  
• Debt to Equity Ratio = Total Liabilities / Total Owner's Equity  
  = 3,143,833.89 / 29,938,987.47  
  ≈ 0.105 (or 0.11)

5. From the cash flow statement, the Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities is –16,772,398.72.  
 We use current liabilities as the “debt” measure.  
• Cash Flow to Debt Ratio = Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities / Total Liabilities  
  = –16,772,398.72 / 3,143,833.89  
  ≈ –5.34

Thus, the final calculated figures are:

{
  "solution": {
    "Current Ratio": "7.15",
    "Quick Ratio": "5.05",
    "Debt to Asset Ratio": "0.10",
    "Debt to Equity Ratio": "0.11",
    "Cash Flow to Debt Ratio": "-5.34"
  }
}
